title: P.M. Update: Rain arrives Wednesday morning, may be heavy at times in the afternoon
text:
The hunter's moon over the Capital Wheel on Monday night. (George Jiang/Flickr)

Temperatures were down a notch today, with most spots rising to near or just past 70. That’s still slightly warm for the time of year, but we’re about to change that up for the next few days. It is a pleasantly cool evening ahead for any outdoor plans, including the Nationals game. Tomorrow, we see some much-needed rain, finally.

Listen to our daily D.C. forecasts: Apple Podcasts | Amazon Echo | More options

Through Tonight: We stay clear through the evening before clouds thicken and lower once deep into the night and toward sunrise. Lows range across the 50s, as winds come from the southeast and south around 5 mph.

View the current weather at The Washington Post.

[Drought denter? A brief soaking rain is likely in D.C. area Wednesday from developing storm.]

Tomorrow (Wednesday): Rain chances are up as we get past sunrise. It looks like most or all of the morning commute should be dry, but rain is probably picking up across the area by midmorning and into lunchtime or so. The most widespread and consistent rain comes during the afternoon, when it could be heavy at times and some thunder may mix in. As much as an inch or so may fall locally. High temperatures occur early, perhaps as mild as just into the 60s. Temperatures should fall back to the 50s in the rain. Winds are out of the south around 5 to 10 mph early but turning to the northwest with time, and turning gusty in the evening.

See David Streit’s forecast through the weekend. And if you haven’t already, join us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram. For related traffic news, check out Gridlock.

So dry: Before the rain fell Sunday (Washington picked up 0.12 inches), we were in the midst of one of the driest 45-day stretches on record. Only 0.27 inches was recorded over the 45 days ending Oct. 12. The only periods with less rain ended in January 1956 with 0.23 inches, October 1930 with 0.25 inches and October 1884 with 0.25 inches.

Weather models tend to indicate that tomorrow’s storm is just the start of a pattern that will continue to deliver more rain. Fingers crossed!
